cab.content: the Cabinet to their decision of the 12th.May which read as follows:-Ex-Enemy Ships. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum " by the Shipping Controller submitt:r^;; Ior their approval an agreement made with Ivn. Paul Bignon the French Minister of Shipping in regard to the ultimate disposal cf enemy tonnage (Paper CP. 1241.The Cabinet approved the Agreement,This decision was however held in abeyance asfurther negotiations were commenced by the French Shippingrepresentatives - these negotiations have now resulted in theattached agreement which was signed on the.14th?December1920 by the Shipping Controller subject to ratification byH*iv;. Government and by Mr Paul Bignon subject to the approvalof the President du Conseil.Under this Agreement and the accompanying lettersthe whole of the German tonnage under French management is tobe left to France for final ownership and the whole of theAustrian tonnage under French management is to be transferred 'by France to Italy or Jugo siaviaaIn return France agrees:-(1) to give up all claims on the vesselsstill to be delivered by Germany withthe exception of one half of her shareof the new tonnage to be laid down byGermany *(2) to the final ownership by Great Britain of certain joint prizes taken in Greek ports (others going to France for final ownership,)EX-ENEMY ships the Shipping Controller calls the attention of (3) to co-operate with Great Britain in maintaining the principle that in regard to the shipment of transmigrants no dis-crimination of any kind should be exer-cised in favour of the vessels of the country at whose port they are embarked and further to grant licences to British Steamship Companies enabling them to have equal facilities with French Companies in the shipment of transmigrants from French ports.The Agreement and the letters attached thereto have been approved by the Treasury - the clauses relating to joint prizes having been approved by the Admiralty and the Procurator-General and the letters relating to emigration by the Board of Trade,, The Foreign Office have also concurred in the submission of the Agreement and the letters attached to it, to the Cabinet for final approval.This determination cf the question of the final ownership of the ex-enemy vessels under French management removes a troublesome cause of friction with France and will expedite the final settlement of all questions relating to the final ownership of ex-enemy vessels, France in return gets some vessels which can well be spared by Great Britain as there will be, considerable difficulty in selling to British buyers all those already allotted to Great Britain. . f* n r-AGREEMENT BETWEEN GREAT BRITAIN AND FRANCE WITH REGARD TO THE ULTIMATE DISPOSAL OF, EX-JSMELffi TONNAGE. 14th December, 1920In order to arrange for the whole of the enemy tonnage at present under French management to be allotted or transferred to France for final ownership.1. Great Britain and France agree that the vessels listed in Schedule A shall be allotted to France for final ownership to meet in full France?s claim to Zone 1 of enemy tonnage as determined by the Reparation Commission.2. Great Britain and France agree that the vessels listed in Schedule B shall be allotted by the Reparation Commission to Great Britain for final ownership and shall thereupon be transferred to France 3* This transfer shall be made in strict accordance with paragraph 6 of the Inter-Allied Percentage Agreement of Spa dated 16th July, 1920 except that the amount to be deducted in this respect from the first percentage payment to France and added" to the first percentage payment to Britain shall be one half only cf the total amount of hire and interest on that hire which would ordinarily be payable, 4. France agrees that in so far as the tonnage allotted to France under paragraph 1, and trans-ferred to France under paragraph 2 of this Agreement exceeds the proportionate share of France on classes 1 and 11 in Zone 1 of enemy tonnage, the excess shall be set off against the claims of France on Classes . 1 and 11 of the later Zones of enemy tonnage as those Zones may be fixed by the Reparation Commission, ' . France!s share, up to the amount determined to be the excess, shall be transferred to Great Britain provided that not more than one half of the proportionate share of France of the tonnage to be laid down by Germany under paragraph 5 of Annex 111 Part will of the Treaty of Versailles shell be so transferred,5. France agrees that the definite allotment to final ownership of the joint prizee here stated shall follow the lines adopted in the allocation to temporary management and shall be as follows;-To great. STIHHES 4985ROTOIA 6618SECtTITOS 4499SILESIA 3353SLAVOHIA 4551TKERLSL LORN 3644ViARUNDI 3321109^663 Cher Sir Joseph,Me referant a 1*Accord e fibre la Grande Bretagne et la Prance en date du 20 avril 1920,. au sujet de la division du tonnage ex-ennemi par lequel la Grande Bretagne s'engageait:"a transferor a la France 1500000 tonnes bruts de "tonnage Allemand lequel, bien cue sous gerance "Francaise, aurait normalement ete cede a la Grande "Bretagne en propriete definitive".La ?rance s'engage a ce que les batiments men-ticnnes dans llAnnexe a la presente lettre soient alloues par la Commission des Reparations a la Grande Bretagne en propriety definitive et transfers ensuite a la France sui-vant les conditions du Paragraphs 6 de llAccord precite1.Le transfert de ces batiments est sounds a l1 Accord Lloyd George/Millorand et en consequence aucune location n'est due a leur sujet par la France a la Grande Bretagne,(Sgd) Paul Bignon,Sous-Secretariat d'Etat REPUBLIQUE FRANCAISE* auxTRA j'SPORTS MARI TIMES Lond-rea, le 14 Decembre 1920.et a lamakiik marcbmds. Bepublique Prancaise, Londres le 14- Dec ombre 1920Oher Sir Joseph,La France s'engage a accepter, c offline faisant par tie du tonnage qui lui revient dans la ;,one 1, la totalite du tonnage Austro-Hongrois, actuellement sous sa ge re nee.La France s'engage a transferor a lfItalie et a la Yougo-Slavie le tonnage ez-Austro-liongrois qufelle a dans sa part.Des Accords particuliers entre les nations interessees rogleront les Conditions de ces remises..i'in raison de la cession des batiments ex-All emands par la "ranie bretagne a la France, le Qouverne-ment Franca is ne fera au rouvernement Italian aucune demands de navires entrant dans la part du tonnage allemand qui reviendrait a ce dernier dans les zones !i, 3 et 4.(Sgd) Paul Bignon. Ministry of hipping, St. James Park,London, P.P.I.14th DecemberJoar Loneiour Bignon,lo , Pith -eferenco to /the question of the shipmentat ports in various countries of emigrants belonging to other countriest which we regard as one of the essential matters UDon which it is necessary to reach an understanding in connection wi^th the new ex-enemy tonnage agreement between Prance and Great Britain, I understand that the French Government are willing tov join Pis Lajesty's Government in maintaining the principle that in such esses no discrimination of any hind should be exercised in favour of the vessels of the country to which the .orts belong. 2c I should be glad if you would, therefore,intimate the formal concurrence of your Government, after which diplomatic notes will be exchanged in the ordinary way.(Sgd) J.P. Paclay. Rep ub 1 i que iy r ane a is e,Lunares le 14 D^cembre 1920.Cher Sir Joseph,i'ar votre lettre en date du^ 14 D^cembre vous aves "bien voulu me faire savoir que 1*attention du Q^iiveriiement de S.' h--;;este a ete attirecsur la question de Pembar clement, dsns difference pays, dferiigrants ap oartenant a d'autres pays et vous mfav9Z demands si le Gcuvernement liVanoais serait dispose a se ioindre au Crouvernement ae 3,-- i^jeste pour le maintien du principe que, dans le cas considere, aucune difference dfaucune sorts ne doit etre faite en faveur des Nuvires du pays, auuuel Is port appartient.Jfai Phonneur de vous faire savoir cue le Grouvernement Ihvncais est dTaccord pour ajir dans le sens que vous indiquea.(S,;d) Pol Bi;non* - Ministry of Shirking,10 St.James,London S .-V. I.14th December, 1920.Dear Monsieur Bignon,With further reference to the question oi the treatment of trans-migrants passing through France, it was understood that whilst France was not prepared to accept a general clause in an Agreement between Prance and Great Britain on this subject, France was prepared to make definite arrangements to issue the necessary licenoe etc., to particular British Companies, and I have,, in this connection, to call your attention to the case of the Royal Mail Steam Packet Company.-- It is understood that they applied to the French Foreign Office for a licence to embark transmigrants passing through France to Cherbourg, and that they, in reply, received a letter from the Secretaire d! tat au Ministers des Dravaux Publics, dated 10th November, stating that as the French Steamship' Companies were able to assure the conveyance of all emigrants going to South America, a licence to an..english Company could not be issued.' I should, therefore, be glaa if you would be so good as to give me an assurance that if the Royal Hail Steam Packet Company renew their application, their application will be granted by the French Government,. and that if applications are made by other British Steamship Companies,, they will granted.In order,, also, that there may be rtno discrimination infavour of the vessels of the oountry to which the ports belong" Isheuld be glad to. have your assuranoe that suoh licence will not contain any stipulation of the following nature(1) that the licence shall be granted only to applicants who bind themselves to embark the majority of their emigrants in French steamers.(2) that the agent is forbidden to confide his passengers to Shipping Company not embarking their emigrants in a French p^rt an a direct steamer. .(Sgd) J.P.Maolay. as-Secretariat d!Etatdes KSPUBIIQUE STRAMOAISB,cIRAK SPORT lOfclTIMBS Londres, le 14 Deoembre 1920.et de laMABIK3 MARCJI.1!Ij)13,Cher Sir Joseph,Ma reierant a votre lettre du 14 oourant coneernant la demande faite par la "ROYAL MIX SIjSaLI PACKS I Co" drembar-quer des emigrants en transit par la France, jfai 1'Jionneur de vous faire savoir que si la "ROYAL MAIL STl-ihiia PACKST CVr ou toute autre Compagnie de navigation Britannique bien etablie fait une demands de licence pour embarquer des emigrants en transit par la France cette licence iui Bera aooordee, Slle ne contiendra auoune stipulation de 1'ordre suivant;l*-'.*ue la licence ne sera accordee qu1 a des Compagniess t. *qui s' eagageront a embarquer la majcrlte de leurs emigrants sur des batiments 2'rancais;2.-^u'il est interdit a lfAgent de confier ses passagers a une Oompagnie ds navigation qui nfembarquerait pas ses emi-grants dans un port francais, sur un navire faisant directe-ment route pour son port de destination.II est bien entendu. toutefdis;li-Qua" toute mesure de reoiprooite devra, le oas eoheant etre aoceptee par la Grande Bretagne qui s^ngagera, en outre a soutenir la France vis a vis d!autres nations dans des oas du meme genre, si la France le desirait; (Sgd. Paul Bignon*2.- Que dans le cas ou lumbar quement des emigrants dans un ' port de France aurait lieu sur un navire destine a les oonduire en Angleterrfc, en vue d'un transbordement, le navire qui les embarcuerait en France devrait etre sounis a la striote obser-vation de toutes les mesures sanitairee, de police ou autres, auxquelles aurait du etre soumis le batircent qui les aurait embarquss en France pour leur destination definitive; autant qUe ces mesurss sout applicables a un pins court voyage.5.-Que la licence serait donuee dans les conditions qui ont deja indiquees a propos de la demende anterieure de la Go CUNAilD, cTest a dire que la Cornpagaie devra oboisir un Agent de nationalite franoaise payant sa propre patente, son propre loyer; ses employes, etc, et qui ne soit pas fonctionnaire de la Oompagnie,Cet Agent reoevrait une licence dans les memes condl-tions que les autres Agents.iCette licence serait domiee pour un an et renouvelable ipar tacite reconduction,
